Description: Egyptian terracotta naked female figure. Head and lower legs missing. Her hair is worn long, her hands are bound behind her back. Hand-made(?) and solid, coated with white material. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with black core, abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Male captives, made of both terracotta and stone, have been found from the Late Period settlements of Tell Dafana in Egypt. This appears to depict a female captive/prisoner, which is not common, but attested associated with magical texts, concerning 'love spells'.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.277) (Phase 1)
